DataElement.preferredName: Normal Tissue Segment Distance From Tumor Surgical Margin Measurement
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The distance in centimeters of non-neoplastic ("normal") tissue from malignant neoplasm tissue after surgical resection of the tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Normal Tissue Segment Distance From Tumor Surgical Margin
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Sufficient total material from each patient, divided to yield a minimum of one aliquot, preferably divided into one to three aliquots of non-neoplastic ("normal") adjacent tissue (as feasible) suitable for processing for proteomic and genomic analysis._The space separating two objects or points._Used to indicate a specified place or time as a starting point; used to indicate a source, cause, agent, or instrument._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Sufficient total material from each patient, divided to yield a minimum of one aliquot, preferably divided into one to three aliquots of non-neoplastic ("normal") adjacent tissue (as feasible) suitable for processing for proteomic and genomic analysis.

Concepts.definition: Tissue sample with cellular composition and architectural patterns expected for the particular anatomic site in which it belongs. There is no evidence of abnormal cellular infiltrates or tumor mass formation.

Property.preferredDefinition: The space separating two objects or points.:Used to indicate a specified place or time as a starting point; used to indicate a source, cause, agent, or instrument.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Concepts.definition: The space separating two objects or points.
Used to indicate a specified place or time as a starting point; used to indicate a source, cause, agent, or instrument.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.

DataElementConcept.origin: CPTAC: Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 2/15/21 jk Released, per SME (NGM) review and approval. 9/23/20 jk created CPTAC Solid tumor procurement CRF.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part.::2_A single character in a numbering system._A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch._Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part.::2:A single character in a numbering system.:A centimeter is a basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.:Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
A single character in a numbering system.
A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.
Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.
